facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 382 of 1960 before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 382 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated October 31, 1957 of Judicial Commissioners Court of Himachal Pradesh at Simla in Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 8 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 31, 1957, of the Judicial Commissioners Court of Himachal Pradesh at Simla in Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 8, of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant was plaintiff in the suit and former ruler of the State of Bhagat, one of the Simla Hill states.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was plaintiff in the suit was the former ruler of the State of Bhagat, one of the Simla Hill states.

facts.text: State of Bhagat and several other Simla Hill States merged in Himachal Pradesh on July 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bhagat and several other Simla Hill States were merged in Himachal Pradesh on July 1, 1947.

facts.text: As consequence of merger, ruler surrendered sovereignty to new State.

anchor.surface_text: As a consequence of the merger the ruler surrendered his sovereignty to the new States.

facts.text: Khasra Nos. 70, 80, 81, 167, 263/170, 171, 172, 173 and 2691177 measuring 15 bighas and 19 biswas declared private property of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Khasra Nos. 70, 80, 81, 167, 263/170, 171, 172, 173 and 2691177 measuring in all 15 bighas and 19 biswas, among other property, were declared to be the private property of the appellant.

facts.text: Fields are appellant's Khudkhast lands, recorded as such in revenue papers since 1936.

anchor.surface_text: It is the appellants case that these fields are his Khudkhast lands, that they are recorded as much in the revenue papers ever since the year 1936

facts.text: Defendants granted licence to cultivate lands on behalf of appellant with obligation to hand over entire produce at end of every year.

anchor.surface_text: and that the defendants were granted licence to cultivate these lands on his behalf with the obligation that the entire produce from the lands should be handed over by them to the appellant at the end of every year.

facts.text: Consideration for arrangement was remission in rent and land revenue granted by appellant to respondents on other lands leased to them.

anchor.surface_text: The consideration for the arrangement was a remission in rent and land revenue which the appellant had granted to the respondents with respect to certain other lands which were leased out by him to the respondents.

facts.text: Bulk of other lands declared State property post merger, respondents have to pay full assessment or rent.

anchor.surface_text: Bulk of these lands were declared to be the State property as a result of the merger and presumably the respondents have to pay full assessment or rent with respect to them.

facts.text: Respondents failed to hand over annual produce from fields in suit.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant the respondents failed to hand over the annual produce from the fields in suit to him

facts.text: Appellant leased lands to Chuku Koli at Rs. 500 per annum for one year from October 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and, therefore, he leased out the lands at Rs. 500/- per annum to Chuku Koli for Rs. 500/- for a period of one year from October, 1950.

facts.text: Respondents obstructed Chuku Koli in taking possession and kept him out despite demands.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, however, obstructed Choku in taking possession of the land and despite repeated demands by the appellant, they kept him out of possession.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit for possession and mesne profits from Rabi 1950 to Kharif 1953 at Rs. 500 per annum and future profits in July 1954.

anchor.surface_text: He therefore instituted a suit for possession and mesneprofits from Rabi 1950 to Kharif 1953 at m. 500 per annum and future profits in July, 1954.

facts.text: Respondents contended they were occupancy tenants for last two or three generations, cultivating jointly and severally.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents it was contended that they were the occupancy tenants of these lands for the last two or three generations. that they were cultivating these lands jointly and severally

facts.text: Suit not cognizable by civil court according to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: and that the suit was number cognizable by a civil court.

facts.text: Respondents filed suit against appellant in court of Assistant Collector First Grade Solon for declaration of possession as occupancy tenants, sought stay of appellant's suit.

anchor.surface_text: They also contended that had filed a suit against the appellant in the court of the Assistant Collector, First Grade, Solon for a declaration to the effect that they are in possession of the lands as occupation tenants and that, therefore, the appellants suit should be stayed.

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit of appellant against all respondents including mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court decreed the suit of the appellant as against all the respondents including the claim for mesne profits.

facts.text: District Judge Mahau dismissed respondents' appeal and confirmed trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents preferred an appeal before the District Judge, Mahau. He dismissed the appeal and confirmed the decree of the trial court.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner allowed second appeal, held respondents were occupancy tenants, s.77(3) with first proviso bars civil court jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: They therefore preferred second appeal to the Court of Judicial Commissioner. The Judicial Commissioner allowed the appeal holding that the respondents were occupancy tenants of the lands and that consequently the provisions of s. 77 (3) read with the first proviso thereto barred the jurisdiction of the civil court.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner set aside decree of trial court and District Judge, directed return of plaint for presentation to proper court.

anchor.surface_text: On this finding the Judicial Commissioner set aside the decree granted by the trial court and affirmed by the District Judge and directed that the plaint be returned for presentation to proper court.

facts.text: District Judge finding based on entries in record of rights from 1936 showing lands as khudkhast lands of appellant in his possession.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt in our mind that the learned Judicial Commissioner was in error in reversing the finding of fact of the District Judge particularly so because the finding of the District Judge is based upon a consideration of entries in the record of rights from the year 1936 onwards showing that the lands were the khudkhast lands of the appellant and were in his possession,

facts.text: Punjab Tenancy Act 1887 applies to Himachal Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: but is triable by a revenue court under s. 77 of the Punjab Tenancy Act, 1887 (Punj. XVI of 1887) hereinafter referred to as the Act which applies to Himachal Pradesh.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Judicial Commissioner erred in interfering with District Judge's finding of fact.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated the appellant challenged the finding of the Judicial Commissioner on the point on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to reverse the finding of the District Court because it was a finding of fact on the question.

facts.text: Entries in revenue records have presumptive value under s.44 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner has omitted to bear in mind the provisions of s. 44 of the Act which give a presumptive value to the entries in revenue records.

but is triable by a revenue court under s. 77 of the Punjab Tenancy Act, 1887 (Punj. XVI of 1887) hereinafter referred to as the Act which applies to Himachal Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Section 77 (3) and the first proviso there to run as follows The following suits shall be instituted in, and heard and determined by Revenue Courts, and no other Court shall take cognizance of any dispute or matter with respect to which, any such suit might be instituted- Provided that- (1) where in a suit cognizable and instituted in a Civil Court it becomes necessary to decide any matter which can under this sub-section be heard and determined only by a Revenue Court shall endorse upon the plaint the nature of the matter for decision and the particulars required by Order VII, rule 10, Code of Civil procedure and return the plaint for presentation to the Collector.

(3) and the second is that the existence of the relationship of landlord and tenant should be admitted by the parties.

holdings.text: The Court of the Judicial Commissioner was wrong in holding that the suit was not triable by a civil court but is triable by a revenue court under s. 77 of the Punjab Tenancy Act, 1887 as the relationship of landlord and tenant is not admitted by the parties

anchor.surface_text: It is contended before us by Mr. Achhru Ram for the appellant that for a suit to be barred under s. 77 (3) of the Act from the cognizance of a civil court two conditions have to be satisfied. The first is that the suit should relate to one of the matters described in sub-s. (3) and the second is that the existence of the relationship of landlord and tenant should be admitted by the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All suits listed under s.77(3) presuppose an admitted landlord-tenant relationship; no provision for cases where tenancy status is disputed; confirmed by textual analysis, scheme of the section, and precedents from Lahore High Court and Supreme Court in Magiti Sasamal

holdings.text: For a suit to be barred under s.77(3) from civil court cognizance, two conditions must be satisfied: (1) suit relates to matters in sub-s.(3), (2) landlord-tenant relationship admitted by parties

anchor.surface_text: It is contended before us by Mr. Achhru Ram for the appellant that for a suit to be barred under s. 77 (3) of the Act from the cognizance of a civil court two conditions have to be satisfied. The first is that the suit should relate to one of the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's contention accepted based on analysis of s.77(3) entries all assuming admitted tenancy, absence of provision for disputed status, and supporting precedents

holdings.text: The relationship of landlord and tenant as between the parties to the suit is not admitted by the appellant, hence s.77(3) does not apply

anchor.surface_text: The observations of this Court would clearly apply to the present case also inasmuch as the relationship of landlord and tenant as between the parties to the suit is riot admitted by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Magiti Sasamal observations to facts where appellant denies tenancy

holdings.text: The Court of the Judicial Commissioner was in error in interfering with the finding of fact of the District Judge that the lands were khudkhast lands of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: As already stated the appellant challenged the finding of the Judicial Commissioner on the point on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to reverse the finding of the District Court because it was a finding of fact on the question.

holdings.text: The respondents were not occupancy tenants of the lands

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt in our mind that the learned Judicial Commissioner was in error in reversing the finding of fact of the District Judge particularly so because the finding of the District Judge is based upon a consideration of entries in the record of rights from the year 1936 onwards showing that the lands were the khudkhast lands of the appellant and were in his possession,

holdings.reasoning_summary: District Judge's finding accepted as based on consistent revenue entries showing appellant's khudkhast lands; Judicial Commissioner omitted s.44 presumption

holdings.text: Entries in revenue records have presumptive value under s.44 of the Act; in case of conflict between prior and later entries, the later entry prevails and is presumed correct unless disproved

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner has omitted to bear in mind the provisions of s. 44 of the Act which give a presumptive value to the entries in revenue records. It was argued before us that there are prior entaries which are in conflict with those on which the learned District Judge has relied. It is sufficient to say that where there is such a conflict, it is the later entry which must prevail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct interpretation of s.44 language providing presumption of correctness to entries, with later substituting earlier

anchor.surface_text: Sham Singh v. Amarjit Singh

precedents.cited_proposition: For a suit to be barred under s. 77(3) of the Act from the cognizance of a civil court, the relationship of landlord and tenant must be admitted by the parties.
precedents.cited_holding: It is obvious that the bar under clause (3) is applicable to those cases only in which the relationship of landlord and tenant is admitted and the object of the suit is to determine the nature of the tenancy i.e. whether the status of the tenant falls under sections 5, 6, 7 or 8 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Baru v. Nader

precedents.cited_proposition: For a suit to be barred under s. 77(3) of the Act from the cognizance of a civil court, the relationship of landlord and tenant must be admitted by the parties.

anchor.surface_text: Daya Ram v. Jagir Singh

precedents.cited_proposition: Where in a suit for ejectment the existence of the relationship of landlord and tenant is not admitted by the parties, the civil court has jurisdiction and the suit does not fall under s. 77(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Magiti Sasamal v. Pandab Bissoi

precedents.cited_proposition: The provision bars civil court jurisdiction only for disputes between admitted landlord and tenant; a dispute about the existence of the relationship is not barred.

anchor.surface_text: Daya Ram v. Jagir Singh

precedents.cited_proposition: Where in a suit for ejectment the existence of the relationship of landlord and tenant is not admitted by the parties, the civil court has jurisdiction and the suit does not fall under s. 77(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Magiti Sasamal v. Pandab Bissoi

precedents.cited_proposition: The provision postulates the relationship of landlord and tenant and covers only specified disputes between them; dispute on existence of relationship not covered.
precedents.cited_holding: In other words, s. 17(1) postulates the relationship of tenants and landlord between the parties and proceeds to provide for the exclusive jurisdiction of the Collector to try the five categories of disputes that may arise between the landlord and the tenant.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: It is contended before us by Mr. Achhru Ram for the appellant that for a suit to be barred under s. 77 (3) of the Act from the cognizance of a civil court two conditions have to be satisfied. The first is that the suit should relate to one of the matters described in sub-s. (3) and the second is that the existence of the relationship of landlord and tenant should be admitted by the parties.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt in our mind that the learned Judicial Commissioner was in error in reversing the finding of fact of the District Judge particularly so because the finding of the District Judge is based upon a consideration of entries in the record of rights from the year 1936 onwards showing that the lands were the khudkhast lands of the appellant and were in his possession,

There is no doubt in our mind that the learned Judicial Commissioner was in error in reversing the finding of fact of the District Judge particularly so because the finding of the District Judge is based upon a consideration of entries in the record of rights from the year 1936 onwards showing that the lands were the khudkhast lands of the appellant and were in his possession,

The learned Judicial Commissioner has omitted to bear in mind the provisions of s. 44 of the Act which give a presumptive value to the entries in revenue records. It was argued before us that there are prior entaries which are in conflict with those on which the learned District Judge has relied. It is sufficient to say that where there is such a conflict, it is the later entry which must prevail.
